channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Errant Bombing of Syrian Troops Weakens U.S. Effort to Curb Violence
item.media:description: A damaged building in Aleppo, Syria, on Saturday. Fighter jets fired at least four missiles at opposition neighborhoods in Aleppo on Sunday.
item.description: The accidental killing of Syrian soldiers again exposed the White House’s struggles to put together a coherent strategy in a multisided civil war.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER, MARK MAZZETTI and BEN HUBBARD
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Obama, Keen to Push Israeli-Palestinian Peace, Will Meet With Netanyahu
item.media:description: President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel at the White House in November.
item.description: Aides said he was expected to review his diplomatic achievements at his last visit to the United Nations, and he might press Israel’s leader to move toward reconciliation.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER and PETER BAKER

item.title: The Interpreter: Straightforward Answers to Basic Questions About Syria’s War
item.media:description: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria in Raqqa, in eastern Syria, in 2011.
item.description: An explanation of the many reasons behind the conflict, its broader context and how it has shaped the refugee crisis and the rise of the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Syria’s Unraveling Truce: ‘My Children Woke Up, Again, to Explosions’
item.media:description: Syrian children listening to songs on Friday at an underground amusement park in Erbeen, east of Damascus.
item.description: Moments of relief during a cease-fire have not created a sense of security or alleviated the country’s misery.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Pro-Putin Parties Show Strength in Russian Parliament Elections
item.media:description: A voting station in St. Petersburg, Russia, on Sunday. Early results showed the governing party, United Russia, with 46 percent of the vote.
item.description: Early results showed the governing party, United Russia, with 46 percent of the vote in an election marked by low turnout in large cities.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Amatrice Journal: After Quake, an Italian Crisis Unit Races to Rescue a Region’s Heritage
item.media:description: Amatrice, Italy, one week after a 6.2-magnitude earthquake hit the city last month.
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.description: With thousands of relics and books at risk in the rubble, a crisis unit is working tirelessly to retrieve and preserve them.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.category: Ministry of Cultural Heritage and Tourism (Italy)

item.title: Holocaust Survivors’ Needs Grow, and Aid Is Slow to Catch Up
item.media:description: Gyorgy Rozsa, 77, a Holocaust survivor, in his home in Budapest. Survivors’ needs are growing in complexity and cost as they age, and funding from sources that have provided for them over the past two decades is starting to dry up.
item.media:credit: Akos Stiller for The New York Times
item.description: Aging and often infirm and isolated, the remaining survivors require more help even as traditional sources of funding are starting to taper off.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.category: Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany

item.title: 17 Indian Soldiers Killed by Militants in Kashmir
item.media:description: Indian soldiers arriving at the army base, in Uri, Kashmir, that heavily armed militants stormed on Sunday.
item.description: The attack was among the deadliest in the region, where India and Pakistan have been locked in a dispute since they attained independence in 1947.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR and GEETA ANAND

item.title: Film Shines Light on South Korean Spy Agency’s Fabrication of Enemies
item.media:description: Yu Woo-sung, a defector from North Korea, in 2014 in Seoul, South Korea. Mr. Yu, who was cleared after his arrest in 2013 on spying charges, is featured in the film “Spy Nation.”
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.description: A new documentary shows how scores of people were arrested and accused of spying for the North, only to be exonerated years later.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Obama to Push Refugee Aid at U.N., but Critics Say Effort Is Overdue
item.media:description: Hamzeh Jouriyeh, 12, a Syrian refugee, studied a United States map in Jordan last month as his family prepared to be resettled in California. President Obama is set to speak to the United Nations General Assembly about the refugee crisis.
item.description: Even those who praise Mr. Obama’s planned meeting on the refugee crisis wonder why the United States waited so long to mount a global response and why it has taken in so few Syrians.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: The United Nations Explained: Its Purpose, Power and Problems
item.media:description: In June 1945, the United Nations Charter was negotiated by representatives from 50 countries at a conference in San Francisco.
item.media:credit: Gjon Mili/The Life Picture Collection, via Getty Images
item.description: As representatives of the body’s 193 member countries gather for the annual session of the General Assembly, a look at how the institution has attempted to live up to its founders’ ambitions.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Berlin Voters Deal Angela Merkel’s Party Another Blow
item.media:description: People waited to cast their votes in the city-state election in Berlin on Sunday. Chancellor Angela Merkel’s party was dealt a defeat.
item.description: Ms. Merkel’s Christian Democratic Union won about 18 percent of the vote in a state election, not enough to allow it to remain the junior partner in a coalition with the Social Democrats.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: U.S. Admits Airstrike in Syria, Meant to Hit ISIS, Killed Syrian Troops
item.description: The United States military said the planes stopped the attack after a warning from Russia, which said 62 Syrian troops were killed and 100 more wounded.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and MARK MAZZETTI
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Kremlin Says It Wants a Spotless Election, but Locally It Is Marred
item.media:description: Vitaly V. Yerkaev, right, of the People’s Freedom Party, said his posters had been banned and his ads rejected.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: The campaign in Togliatti, long a bastion of opposition to the dominant United Russia Party, illustrates the gap between the promise of fair elections on Sunday and the reality.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Turkey’s Islamic Fashion Revolution
item.media:description: A 2014 show in Istanbul for Modanisa, an Islamic fashion house that has partnerships with brands in Dubai and Malaysia.
item.description: As Europe grapples with the burkini, Islamic dress in Turkey has become a symbol of religious freedom, and the nation has fostered fashion houses, magazines and bloggers.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Southeast Asia Replaces Africa as the World’s Hotbed of Piracy
item.media:description: A group of Indonesian tugboat crew members in the Philippines in May after their release by Abu Sayyaf militants.
item.media:credit: Office of Sulu Governor, via Associated Press
item.description: Militants from Abu Sayyaf and other criminal groups have stepped up kidnappings and thefts in the seas around Indonesia and the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Caliphate in Peril, More ISIS Fighters May Take Mayhem to Europe
item.media:description: Iraqi security forces on patrol late last month as smoke rose from burning oil wells in Qayara.
item.description: The American-led coalition is closing in strongholds in Iraq and Syria. But some Western officials expect consequences to that success for years to come.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Germans and Austrians Protest E.U. Trade Talks With U.S. and Canada
item.description: Opposition to proposed deals, and to perceived lower consumer standards, has united a coalition of churches, trade unions, intellectuals and left-wing parties.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Egypt Freezes Assets of Several Human Rights Advocates
item.description: As part of a criminal investigation, a court froze the assets of five prominent activists and three nongovernmental organizations that document state abuses.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: His Grip Still Secure, Bashar al-Assad Smiles as Syria Burns
item.media:description: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, center, touring the desolation of Daraya on Monday, after government forces seized the town from rebel control.
item.media:credit: Syrian Arab News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Though Mr. Assad’s standing has been diminished, he is able to present himself as the leader his nation needs to get through a war for which he denies any responsibility.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

item.title: Abu Sayyaf Militants Release Norwegian Hostage in Philippines
item.description: The police said the Norwegian man, Kjartan Sekkingstad, whose fellow Canadian hostages were both beheaded this year, had been freed by the group for a ransom.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: Carlo Azeglio Ciampi, Former Italian Prime Minister, Dies at 95
item.media:description: Carlo Azeglio Ciampi, who served as prime minister and president of Italy, with Pope Benedict XVI in Rome in 2005.
item.description: Mr. Ciampi, a respected economist, led the country during a turbulent period and helped usher in the euro.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: What in the World: In Britain’s Parliament, a Crowded House Bursting With Lords
item.media:description: A parliamentary session this month at the House of Lords in London. There is no limit on membership, and members generally serve for life.
item.description: Efforts to overhaul the House of Lords, reduce its membership or abolish it altogether have produced more noise than fundamental change.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: What in the World: What’s Hebrew for ‘When in the Course of Human Events’?
item.media:description: The Declaration of Independence begins with Thomas Jefferson’s famous phrase “when in the course of human events” — and so did an early draft of Israel’s founding document.
item.description: Early drafts of Israel’s founding document borrowed heavily from Thomas Jefferson in the Declaration of Independence, among other famous writings.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Opinion: England’s Forgotten Muslim History
item.media:description: Murad III, left, Elizabeth I, right.
item.media:credit: Ullstein Bild, via Getty Images (left); The Print Collector/Getty Images (right)
item.description: Isolated from Europe, Elizabeth I turned to the Islamic world.
item.dc:creator: JERRY BROTTON
item.category: Elizabeth I, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: So Much Land, Too Few Russians
item.description: A tide of Chinese migration to a corner of Russia’s Far East is the latest example of a history that bends Moscow toward autocracy.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL KHODARKOVSKY
item.category: Ministry for the Development of the Far East (Russia)

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Can a Post-Coup Turkey Get Along with Europe?
item.media:description: An image of Fethullah Gulen during a July rally in Istanbul in support of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
item.description: Both sides have an obligation to try to salvage their relationship.
item.dc:creator: IVAN KRASTEV
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: At the Hajj, Facing Islam’s Inconsistent Embrace of Women
item.media:description: Women at the hajj, clockwise from left: on Ajyad Street, one of the main thoroughfares leading to the Grand Mosque in Mecca; Indonesian women rested on a sidewalk in the tent city of Mina, where nearly 2 million pilgrims slept for three days as part of their hajj rites; and the Times correspondent Diaa Hadid during the hajj.
item.description: Our reporter, on her first hajj, says she “was at once frustrated by Islam’s nitpicky strictures on women’s dress and embraced by its warm sisterhood.”
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Notebook: How Many Guns Did the U.S. Lose Track of in Iraq and Afghanistan? Hundreds of Thousands.
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers after receiving new rifles from U.S. forces in Baghdad in May 2007.
item.description: A new study shows how the American military failed at the soldier’s most basic responsibility: keeping track of firearms.
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: How Russia Often Benefits When Julian Assange Reveals the West’s Secrets
item.media:description: Julian Assange looking out from the Ecuadorean Embassy in London in February. Having lived there for four years, he is increasingly isolated.
item.description: American officials say Mr. Assange and WikiLeaks probably have no direct ties to Russian intelligence services. But the agendas of WikiLeaks and the Kremlin have often dovetailed.
item.dc:creator: JO BECKER, STEVEN ERLANGER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
